Situation1: They handle a busy checkout with a long queue during peak hours.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Story: The line at my register snakes down the aisle, customers shifting impatiently as I scan groceries and count change. My manager’s eyes flick to the clock, reminding me that accuracy and speed are everything, especially during the Saturday rush. I can’t afford mistakes; every transaction must be perfect. But as I ring up another basket, my phone buzzes in my pocket—a reminder that church service starts in fifteen minutes. I promised my pastor I’d help set up for the community lunch afterward, and I know my absence will be noticed. My heart aches with guilt; I want to be there, to worship and serve, to be the Christian I’m expected to be. But I can’t just abandon my post, not with so many people waiting and my coworkers already stretched thin. The weight of both roles presses down on me, each demanding my presence, each with its own expectations. I stare at the growing line, feeling torn, unsure which duty I should honor.
